Award.AwardTitle: Selective, high efficiency anion encapsulation by neutral nanojars
Award.AbstractNarration:
Agents that selectively and efficiently extract anions (negatively charged ions) from water are potentially useful for important applications such as the removal of harmful anions from contaminated lakes and rivers, industrial and agricultural wastes, and of anions interfering with certain technological processes. Dr. Gellert Mezei of Western Michigan University conducts research to gain a better understanding of the mechanism of formation of a new class of agents for binding anions and the binding characteristics of these agents. His research aims to provide fundamental insights important for improving strategies to the design and synthesis of more efficient and selective receptors for anion extractions. In addition to training graduate students, he recruits and engages high school and undergraduate students (especially from underrepresented groups) in research. Through outreach events, such as the activities on the "Chemistry Day at the Museum" at the Kalamazoo Valley Museum, Dr. Mezei and his research group educate the general public about science and the exciting careers available through a degree in science.

This project focuses on the synthesis and study of "nanojars" that selectively encapsulate anions, such as sulfate, phosphate, arsenate and chromate. Each "nanojar" is comprised of three or four macrocyclic copper complexes ([Cu(OH)(pz)]n, where pz=pyrazolate, n=6-14) that self-assemble into a two nanometer-sized supramolecular structure with a large number of hydrogen bonds directed toward an anion inside the jar. A cation serves as a "lid" that seals the nanojar and renders the anion completely buried and inaccessible. The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of NSF supports Dr. Mezei's research group to investigate the mechanism of formation of these nanojars and to understand the thermodynamics of self-assembly and anion encapsulation. New nanojars with substituted pyrazole ligands are designed to enhance their selectivity for certain anions and to impart solubility in solvents of interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background

The extraction of inorganic anions (negatively charged molecules) from certain aqueous environments is an important task, as anions can be harmful to our health and have detrimental effects in various technological processes. For instance, arsenate and chromate are highly poisonous and carcinogenic; phosphate leads to eutrophication of lakes and rivers; sulfate and carbonate lead to scale formation; sulfate and phosphate interfere with the disposal process by vitrification of nuclear wastes. The selective binding and efficient removal of these anions from water, however, is very challenging in certain cases. One major challenge is the selective extraction of anions with large hydration energy (high affinity for water, difficult to extract) in the presence of anions with small hydration energy (low affinity for water, easily extractable). Another challenge is the extraction of anions under conditions that lead to breakdown of the extracting agent, such as high alkalinity or high temperature.

 

Intellectual Merit

This NSF grant aided in developing a novel class of anion extraction agents, termed “nanojars”, which possess a number of distinctive features compared to known anion extraction agents. First, appropriately functionalized nanojars are capable of transferring even the anions with the highest affinity for water, such as carbonate, sulfate and phosphate, from water into organic solvents (such as long-chain aliphatic hydrocarbons, widely used in industry and consumer products), allowing for the removal of such anions from contaminated aqueous media by liquid-liquid extraction. Second, nanojars bind the incarcerated anions with unparalleled strength, attested by the fact that an aqueous Ba2+ solution is unable to precipitate the highly insoluble barium salt of the incarcerated anion, when stirred with a solution of the corresponding nanojars. Third, nanojars only form in the presence of anions bearing 2? or 3? charge (such as the anions mentioned above); therefore, nanojars offer total selectivity for anions with large hydration energy over anions with small hydration energy (such as halides, nitrate, perchlorate, which bear 1? charge). Moreover, we designed and synthesized nanojars that afford even higher selectivity among anions of comparable hydration energies, and achieved selective extraction of carbonate in the presence of large excess of sulfate. Fourth, nanojars display excellent resistance to highly alkaline solutions, allowing for the unprecedented liquid-liquid extraction of ions such as carbonate, sulfate, phosphate, arsenate and chromate from aqueous solution with pH > 14 into hydrocarbon solvents. Importantly, the concentration of the highly toxic arsenate and chromate ions in contaminated aqueous samples was reduced below the current Maximum Contaminant Level established by the Environmental Protection Agency for drinking water. Fifth, nanojars are remarkably stable at high temperatures, such as 150 °C in a dimethylsulfoxide solution, allowing for extraction of anions in a wide window of temperatures.

 

By using an array of complementary characterization techniques, including mass spectrometry, variable-temperature nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, X-ray crystallography, UV-visible spectroscopy, pH titrations and thermogravimetric analysis, the formation mechanism and reactivity profile of nanojars was established. Understanding the intricate properties of nanojars, in turn, aided in developing a recyclable anion extraction system. Thus, the incarcerated/extracted anion can be recovered for reuse or proper disposal, and the nanojar components can be used again for anion extraction.

 

NSF-funded work on nanojars has opened doors toward a variety of unforeseen research directions, and created impact in diverse fields, including theoretical chemistry, organic synthesis and green chemistry. In particular, unexpected outcomes of organic synthesis during the preparation of novel nanojar building-blocks inspired the theoretical investigation of underlying causes, and led to textbook-changing results. For instance, the drastic reactivity difference between six- and five-membered, methyl-substituted aromatic molecules, as well as their different isomers, has been elucidated; also, previously misunderstood concepts, such as the ‘adjacent lone-pair effect’, have been demystified. The new knowledge generated by these studies has already been exploited for the development of new classes of compounds and improved organic synthesis methodologies, including more efficient, telescoping strategies and truly green alternative technologies.

 

This NSF grant already resulted in 14 papers in peer-reviewed journals, and several others are in preparation for publication. The results have also been disseminated at numerous presentations at international, national and regional conferences, universities and national laboratories.

 

Broader Impacts

This NSF grant provided support and/or training and professional development for four graduate, five undergraduate and three high school students (including students traditionally underrepresented in higher education), who contributed directly to this project; most of them have already co-authored publications resulting from their research on nanojars. Several other students benefited from the project and contributed indirectly by conducting research on related topics. The grant also supported outreach events, such as “Sparking Young Children's Interest in Science through Chemical Demonstrations” at a local museum, and to students from a local middle school, aimed at educating the general public about the importance of Chemistry in their everyday life and well-being, and increasing the number of students pursuing careers in science.
